wikipedia_page.main:
Charles Lickfold Warner  (10 October 1846 – 12 February 1909) was an English stage actor.
He was born in Kensington. He first appeared in 1861 at a special performances of Richelieu before Queen Victoria.
He committed suicide by hanging himself in his hotel room at the age of 63.

response: Born in St John's Wood, London, England in 1876, H. B. Warner was educated at Bedford School. His father, Charles Warner, was an actor, and although Henry initially thought about studying medicine, he eventually performed on the stage. He had an older sister, Grace Warner (1873-1925), who was a stage actress and manager.Who Was Who in the Theatre: 1912-1976 vol. 4 Q-Z p.2508 (Grace Warner's bio) - from editions originally published annually by John Parker; 1976 edition by Gale Research Company...Retrieved 23 September 2014

* A Snug Little Kingdom, "A Comedy of Bohemia" in three acts, was performed at the Royalty Theatre, running from 31 January to 28 February 1903 (28 performances). It featured Charles Warner, Lyn Harding and H. B. Warner.J. P. Wearing. The London Stage 1900-1909: A Calendar of Productions, Performers, and Personnel. Page 130. Scarecrow Press 2013.
Charles Warner (1846–1909) was an English stage actor.
Charles Warner may also refer to:

Gordon and Brunton supplied the settings for Charles Warner's 1888 season in Melbourne, which included Charles Reade's Drink, Holcroft's The Road to Ruin, and Lord Lytton's Lady of Lyons at the Royal and the Princess Theatre from March to July 1888.
